heading: 1 Study Premise
text: Body Advocacy Movement Study (Phase 1: 2021-2023) pilot study investigating feasibility, acceptability, preliminary efficacy eating disorder risk reduction intervention developed EMBARK lab 2020.existing, dissonance programs (.e. Body Project) target reductions thin-ideal internalization, fears related fatness weight gain may particularly salient cognitive target among current past eating disorder symptomatology (Levinson et al., 2014). effort mitigate risk ED onset relapse among high-risk young adults (.e. ED partial- full-remission /ongoing subthreshold ED symptoms), current project includes development initial evaluation novel, peer-led intervention focuses specifically fear fatness anti-fat bias (Body Advocacy Movement; BAM).project aims recruit 60 young adults (ages 18-26) – randomized standard dissonance intervention program (Body Project; N = 20) BAM (N = 40). objective examine degree BAM can reduce fear fatness weight gain along internalized anti-fat bias reduce risk ED symptom exacerbation promote ongoing ED recovery high-risk, young adult sample. evaluate feasibility acceptability BAM estimate effects intervention self-report behavioral measures fear weight gain fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. conduct initial effect size comparisons Body Project determine whether BAM shows potency specifically targeting fear fatness anti-fat bias.

heading: 1.1 Specific Aims
text: Aim 1: Examine acceptability feasibility BAM high-risk young adult sample. Acceptability: Acceptability assessed via attrition across 4-session intervention along qualitative feedback brief survey post-intervention. expect meet benchmarks high acceptability (average ratings > 4 [5] post-intervention survey; < 20% attrition). Feasibility: Feasibility benchmarked via intervention adherence (average competency > 8.0 0-10 scale) recruitment goals.Aim 2: Estimate effects intervention fear fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. hypothesize BAM intervention result acute reductions (post-intervention) fatphobia anti-fat bias across self—report behavioral measures, outperforming Body Project targets related anti-fat bias, specifically.

heading: 2 Procedures
text: first wave study include recruitment 60 young adults (ages 18-26) take part intervention improve body image advocate body positivity. Participants randomized Body Project (n = 20) BAM (n = 40). Participants groups complete two peer-led, 2-hour sessions, complete series assessments baseline, post-intervention, 1-month 6-month follow-.

heading: 2.1 Recruitment
text: Recruitment sources include: (1) University Health Services UW-Madison area colleges universities (2) flyers area businesses (e.g. fitness centers, coffee shops) (3) online advertisement social media platforms (4) direct, peer--peer recruitment peer facilitators, (5) campus e-mail recruitment.

heading: 3.1 The Body Project
text: use 2-session, peer-facilitated dissonance-based Body Project Intervention, asks participants engage series exercises critique culturally-sanctioned appearance ideals, specifically targets reductions thin-ideal internalization (Becker et al., 2006).

heading: 3.2 The Body Advocacy Movement
text: BAM leverages dissonance exposure-based intervention strategies, adapting common exercises used promote body acceptance challenge sociocultural body ideals specifically target anti-fat bias internalized fatphobia. Participants BAM (1) Define anti-fat bias fatphobia explore constructs manifest personal beliefs interpersonal interactions, (2) Engage imaginal exposure exercises challenge fears related fatness weight gain (3) Reflect fears fatness align personal values, (4) Learn new ways challenge fear fatness internalized anti-fat bias (5) Discuss ways challenge anti-fat bias institutional societal level. Intervention content. Session 1 include introductions, discussing identities clarifying terminology, exercise defining anti-fat bias fatphobia. Participants asked complete imaginal exposure exercise several times week write recount ‘worst-case scenario’ might fear happen gained significant amount weight. Session 2 include debriefing exposure homework identification ways one might uproot internalized fear fatness, along series role plays peer facilitators play role friend family member situation evokes anti-fat attitudes, participants practice challenging attitudes. Participants also identify ways challenge anti-fat bias society commit engaging one activity coming week. exit exercise, write ‘response letter’ worst-case scenario.

heading: 3.3 Peer Facilitators.
text: employ peer-facilitated model group intervention program, small group 6-10 facilitators undergo 8-hour training program, similar Stice et al. (2017). Peer facilitators train teams – peer-leader team role-play delivery entire intervention observed peer leaders teams , receiving live clinical supervision.

heading: 3.4 Intervention Fidelity.
text: Sessions audio recorded reviewed two members research staff. Audio recorded sessions rated fidelity competence. Research staff independently code randomly selected sample 50% sessions implementation fidelity facilitator competence using checklists assessing major exercises discussion topics session. component rated degree accurate presentation (10-point scale “adherence; section skipped” “Perfect; material section presented written”). Facilitator competence rated using 12 items assessing indicators competence (e.g., leaders express ideas clearly appropriate pace, leaders attempt allot equal speaking time members) 10-point scale.

heading: 5.1 Childhood Trauma Questionnaire
text:
Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ) standardized self-report inventory measures severity childhood trauma participants’ tendency underreport maltreatment, validated clinical non-clinical populations (Bernstein et al., 1997; Villano et al., 2004). CTQ retrospective 28-item self-report inventory measures severity different types childhood trauma, producing five clinical subscales comprised five items: Emotional Abuse, Physical Abuse, Sexual Abuse, Emotional Neglect, Physical Neglect. measure also includes three-item Minimization/Denial scale indicating potential underreporting maltreatment. Participants respond item context “growing ” answer according five-point Likert scale ranging “never” = 1 “often” = 5, producing scores 5 25 trauma subscale. three items comprising Minimization/Denial scale dichotomized (“never” = 0, responses = 1) summed; total one (1) greater suggests possible underreporting maltreatment (false negatives).ScoringScoring CTQ includes:Renaming variables descriptive namesRenaming variables descriptive namesCreating sum scores subscale (5 items 5 subscales)Creating sum scores subscale (5 items 5 subscales)Dichotomizing items minimization scaleDichotomizing items minimization scaleSumming dichotimized items create minimization scoreSumming dichotimized items create minimization scoreKey Variables
Key summary variables CTQ include:
ctq_emo_abuse_complete (CTQ emotional abuse subscale sum - completers )ctq_emo_abuse_NAs (number NA items subscale)ctq_emo_abuse_weighted_sum (CTQ weighted sum scores contributing emotional abuse subscale)ctq_phys_abuse_complete (CTQ pysical abuse subscale sum - completers )ctq_phys_abuse_NAs (number NA items subscale)ctq_phys_abuse_weighted_sum (CTQ weighted sum scores contributing emotional abuse subscale)ctq_sex_abuse_complete (CTQ sexual abuse subscale sum - completers )ctq_sex_abuse_NAs (number NA items subscale)ctq_sex_abuse_weighted_sum (CTQ weighted sum scores contributing sexual abuse subscale)ctq_emo_neglect_complete(CTQ emotional neglect subscale sum - completers )ctq_emo_neglect_NAs (number NA items subscale)ctq_emo_neglect_weighted_sum (CTQ weighted sum scores contributing emotional neglect subscale)ctq_phys_neglect_complete(CTQ physical neglect subscale sum - completers )ctq_phys_neglect_NAs (number NA items subscale)ctq_phys_neglect_weighted_sum (CTQ weighted sum scores contributing emotional neglect subscale)ctq_minimize (CTQ minimization score - completers )

heading: 5.6 Eating Pathology Symptom Inventory
text: used 45-item Eating Pathology Symptom Inventory (EPSI; (Forbush et al., 2013)) assess eating disorder symptoms pre-intervention, post-intervention, 8-week follow-. EPSI validated clinical, college, community samples, 7-8 subscales various populations, 8-subscale version commonly-employed version measure (Coniglio et al., 2018). 8 subscales includ: Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, Negative Attitudes toward Obesity, Muscle Building. item scored 5-point Likert-style scale (0 = Never; 4= Often) describe well item describes participant experiences. Scores derived summing responses across questions included subscale.ScoringTo clean data, scoresheet:selects variables relevant current measureselects variables relevant current measurerename raw variables appropraite names easy understandrename raw variables appropraite names easy understandcreates eight additional variables based sum scores reflecting eight subscales questionnaire: Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, Negative Attitudes toward Obesity, Muscle Buildingcreates eight additional variables based sum scores reflecting eight subscales questionnaire: Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, Negative Attitudes toward Obesity, Muscle Buildingselect columns go final datasetselect columns go final datasetKey VariablesThe variables sum different subscales. Sum variables exclude complete items subscaleepsi_body_dissatisfaction (reflects participant’s body dissatisfaction symptoms)epsi_binge_eating (reflects participant’s binge eating symptoms)epsi_cognitive_restraint (reflects participant’s cognitive restraint symptoms)epsi_purging (reflects participant’s purging symptoms)epsi_restricting (reflects participant’s restricting symptoms)epsi_excessive_exercise (reflects participant’s excessive exercise symptoms)epsi_negative_attitude (reflects participant’s negative attidtude towards obesity symptoms)epsi_muscle_building (reflects participant’s muscle building symptoms)

heading: 5.8 Food Security Questionnaire
text:
companion file Household Food Security Scale (FSQ) developed USDA Food Nutrition Services (FNS) 1995 assessing food security within households, specifically use Current Population Survey (CPS) run US Bureau Census (Carlson et al., 1999). One distinguishing factors FSQ categorical approach unidimensional scale intended measure severity food insecurity question (Carlson et al., 1999). FSQ demonstrates strong psychometric properties high reliability validity supported historical evaluations (Engelhard Jr. et al., 2018). FSQ uses 3 separate scales different types questions: yes questions 2-point likert scale, questions 3 point likert scale, wherein, 2 equals never true 0 equals often true, questions 6-point likert scale 1 equals days 7 equals everyday.Measuring Food Insecurity Hunger United States: Development National Benchmark Measure Prevalence EstimatesUsing Household Fit Indices Examine Psychometric Quality Food Insecurity MeasuresScoring

heading: 5.10 Goldfarb Fear of Fat Scale
text:
Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale (GFFS) introduced 1985 diagnostic tool measure one’s fear fat can indicator development eating disorder (Goldfarb et al., 1985). used screening tool clinical non-clinical groups, GFFS strong test-retest reliability psychometric properties (Pryzbyla-Basista et al., 2022). addition, test also shown high validity populations without eating disorders (Goldfarb, 2010). GFFS uses 4-point scale 1 equal untrue 4 equal true, 1-factor solution supported scoring.Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale
examination factor structure Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale clinical non-clinical samples Polish women

heading: 5.12 Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS)
text:
companion file Positive Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) introduced 1988 two-factor scale measure one’s positive negative moods (Watson et al., 1988). Compared scales measuring positive negative affect, PANAS high internal consistency validity (Watson et al., 1988). addition, scale also shows consistent reliabiltiy, even measured across sexes (Crawford et al., 2004). PANAS uses 5-point likert scale 1 equal slightly 5 equal extremely. terms scoring, sums scores separated questions regarding positive affect questions reagrding negative affect.Development Validation Brief Measures Positive Negative Affect: PANAS Scales
Positive Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS): Construct validity, measurement properties normative data large non-clinical sample

heading: 5.14 Traditional Masculinity-Femininity Scale
text: companion file Traditional Masculinity-Femininity Scale (TMFS) introduced 2016 assess self-ascribed masculinity femininity (Kachel et al., 2016). TMFS demonstrated high reliability sexes (Kachel et al., 2016). Additionally, TMFS shows validity due ability reduce issues social desirability given self-assessment (Kachel et al., 2016). TMFS uses 7-point likert scale 1 equal totally masculine 7 equal totally feminine. terms scoring, mean taken given answers average less 4 implying masculinity average greater 4 implying femininity.Traditional Masculinity Femininity: Validation New Scale Assessing Gender RolesScoresheetIn order clean data:Select raw variables usedSelect raw variables usedRename variables include numbering questions scaleRename variables include numbering questions scaleAverage total scores rename tmfs_meanAverage total scores rename tmfs_meanKey Variablestmfs_mean (average scores response questions asking different situations one consider femininity masculinity)

heading: 5.15 Universal Measure of Bias - Fat
text:
companion file Universal Measure Bias - Fat (UMB-Fat) introduced 2008 assess weight bias demonstrates strong psychometric properties utilized assessment (Durso et al., 2008). compared alongside two scales measuring universal bias ‘gay’ ‘Muslim’ individuals demonstrates high internal consistency construct validity (Latner et al., 2008). UMB-Fat uses 7-point likert scale 1 equal strongly agree 7 equal strongly disagree. terms scoring, sums scores separated amongst four categories bias: adverse judgement, social distance, attraction, equal rights.Understanding self-directed stigma: development weight bias internalization scale

heading: 6.1.1 Scoring
text:
IAT scoring algorithm involves several steps, rigorous scoring procedure involving 12 specifications (Greenwald et al., 2003)Steps include:Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Eliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msEliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msUse remaining trialsUse remaining trialsNo extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)Compute mean correct latencies blockCompute mean correct latencies blockCompute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Compute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Replace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msReplace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msNo transformationNo transformationAverage resulting values four blocksAverage resulting values four blocksCompute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Compute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Average two quotients Step 11Average two quotients Step 11R code used cleaning Weight-IAT data prior implementing scoring algorithm available - yet available.

heading: 6.2 Weight Based Approach Avoidance Task (Weight-AAT)
text: interactive task manipulate congruency reward- threat-related outcomes – task derived Weaver et al. (2020). Participants learn, trial--error, three responses, indicated geometric shapes, select achieve particular outcome. Critically, response option associated probability reward outcome (points) additional outcome (.e., images body parts larger bodies). response-outcome contingencies (e.g., option likely lead reward) switch throughout task, half time option likely lead reward also likely lead seeing large body images (Conflict Phase), half time highest reward option least likely lead seeing large body images (Congruent Phase) . Participants instructed earn many points possible (reward goals), allowing us test biases decision-making large body images likely. trial, participants choose shape, , delay (.5-.75s), point outcome trial appeared image (presented 1.5–2.5s) image remained screen, indicating positive negative value (e.g., +5 -7). Trials separated fixation cross, presented .5-1.5s. type image (trauma-related neutral) direction points (positive, negative) experimentally manipulated reflect probabilities aligned type phase. number points won/lost randomly generated (range: 1-10). Task Phases counterbalanced order allow initial task structure learning introduction Conflict Phase.trials, outcomes (image type, point win/loss) either 80%, 50%, 20% chance occurring. image type point win/loss probabilities independent one another. Probabilities outcome left right shape (circle hexagon) adjusted throughout task create Conflict Congruent Phases.

heading: 6.2.1.1 Difference Score
text: can also create crude individual difference score represent discrepancy two task phases (Mean Conflict Phase points - Mean Congruent Phase Points), higher difference score reflecting higher degree conflict two phases.

heading: 6.2.1.2 Linear Mixed Effects Model
text:
Code scoring Weight-AAT using Linear mixed Effects Model Approach available - yet availableWeight-AAT task data housed (long-format) data set within study database, keys subject_id timepoint.Linear Mixed Effects Model uses trial-wise outcomes (.e. modeling outcomes trials participant). Prior analysis, predictors outcomes scaled analysis including block, Phase (Conflict = -1, Congruent - 1), Trial (z-scored within block) regressed Total Points (scaled 0 1). Trial coded account learning within block (e.g. trial number 1-25 z-scored represent linear learning throughout trial).Ultimate outputs model include random intercept random slope Phase, Block, Trial, interactions account individual variability – e.g:
Points ~ Phase + Trial + Block + Phase * Trial + Phase * Block + Trial * Block + Phase * Trial * Block + Age + Gender + (1+Phase * Trial * Block|sub)examine BMI differences, Phase * BMI Phase * Trial * BMI interaction may also introduced model

heading: 7 Sample Description
text:
2021, ran pilot version program (N = 29) randomizing young adults either 2-session Body Project Body Advocacy Movement (BAM; described ) intervention (see Figure 1 Pilot enrollment). Average fear fatness full sample baseline similar samples ‘repeat dieters’ (Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale average Baseline = 23.26), lower clinical samples active EDs. subsample second wave recruitment completed measure ED history, questions specifically assessing ED diagnostic criteria. Among subsample participants, 60% reported history symptoms consistent full-threshold ED diagnosis (= 33%, BN = 20%, BED = 7%) additional 20% reported history subthreshold symptoms (Driven exercise lose weight = 13%, Subclinical BED = 7%).
